newsitem.title: USA: Intuit finds MacInTax software problem.
newsitem.headline: Intuit finds MacInTax software problem.

text.p: Intuit Inc. said Monday it notified all customers who electronically filed their tax returns using its MacInTax programme that they may have filed an incomplete return because of a software problem.
It said it estimates the problem affects less than one-half percent of all the returns filed electronically with MacInTax.
A company spokeswoman said the problem affects only those customers who filed their returns prior to March 1, and who failed to save their work immediately prior to electronically filing.

"We understand the importance of accuracy in financial matters, which is why we stand 100 percent behind our customers," said Larry Wolfe, vice president and general manager of Intuit's Personal Tax Division.

"This situation involving MacInTax is absolutely covered under our guarantee. If a customer has filed an incomplete electronic return with MacInTax, Intuit will pay the penalty plus any interest assessed by the IRS."

Those returns were sent in an incomplete form, containing only the material that was last saved. However, after March 1, the company added a feature to detect those incomplete filings and notify customers.
Intuit's stock was off $1.125 at $21.50 on the Nasdaq market.
